Reviews.Title: “Not for tourists!”
Reviews.Author: darkscot
Reviews.Content: This hotel is on the Asian side of Istanbul, so if you are visiting as a tourist you are in the wrong part of town. Take a look at a map! The hotel itself is very nice and clean with good facilities. I didn't spend much time at the hotel apart from to sleep and do some work. There was free wi-fi in the room but that got very slow in the evening, presumably when lots of people were using it. The location is not very attractive but it is certainly not an "industrial estate". There are lots of good resturants close by, many within walking distance. Bagdad street which has lots of shopping and bars/resturants is only about ten minutes away by taxi. I paid about Â£250 for three nights including breakfast would happily stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Business in Turkey”
Reviews.Author: erikallie
Reviews.Content: Convenient for business in the immediate area due to the ever increasing traffic problems that Istanbul suffers. Once a very nice property, it now shows quite a bit of 'use'. Staff are polite and very professional. Rooms are clean but sparse and run down. It is not uncommon to have to wait 7 - 10 minutes for one the only two elevators that service the entire building. Not so much of a problem going down, but for climbing to the 14th floor or so, be prepared to wait! The advertised bar and restaurant on the top floor are no longer in service. There is a buffet restaurant on the ground floor but it seems to be always reserved for companies paying for workers servicing local businesses, leaving a small garden restaurant where the food is mediocre at best. Buffet breakfast was plentiful and well prepared. The gym and Turkish Hammam offered is a very nice plus, although roughly half of the machines were not operating properly.

Reviews.Title: “Just OK, overpriced”
Reviews.Author: EmmeVi
Reviews.Content: I have been here a couple of times: overall acceptable although quite expensive if compared to other Istanbul hotels with the same or higher quality standards. I found the rooms to be clean, although the furniture was quite old; the same for common areas. Friendly staff at reception even if quite slow. Allegedly there were two restaurants, only the one on the ground floor was working; on the second night it was fully booked for a private function and we were invited to seat in the bar and have dinner there (in the dark). Food quality was acceptable but once again quite expensive. On the last day we had breakfast at 7.00: the room was open but the buffet was not fully prepared yet (breakfast was supposed to start at 6.30)

Reviews.Title: “Incredible Istanbul”
Reviews.Author: Cliff C
Reviews.Content: My first visit to Istanbul- a wonderful city but with only two bridges the traffic is a nightmare. You have to be patient because getting anywehre takes a long time!

Reviews.Title: “not for tourists”
Reviews.Author: leilaferguson
Reviews.Content: The good things about this hotel were the outside pool which no one else sat at and the free wifi. The rooms were fine and the staff generally tried their best. However, as has been mentioned before this is a) not a 5 star hotel and b) not a tourist hotel. It is in the middle of an industrial estate, no one takes travellers cheques and we had to take a 2 hour taxi ride into the centre of Istanbul to change our money. Besides breakfast which was ok we only had one meal in the hotel which was very expensive and my main course was brought out and left on the side while I was still eating the starter. Food was good though. Overall I should have not let myself be swayed by the 5 star rating and read Trip Advisor before booking! OK if you just want to get away and chill I guess. oh and the air conditioning didnt work and the bath leaked!

Reviews.Title: “Definetly a 3 star experience”
Reviews.Author: mendjanbranko
Reviews.Content: Situated in far end of Bostanci, near various car shops and abandoned construction sites, with not so much of a view, this hotel is rated 5 star for unknown reasons. Staff does not know English, hotel restaurant is not working during the day and prices are sky high. It's good thing that nearby is good shop and few good restaurants, so i didn't die from hunger or dehydration. Bathrooms are old, wireless internet doesn't exist (they sent guy to brim me UTP cable for network), they didn't bother to bring my bags to my room (not that i've required it, but then, it's 5 star hotel, isn't it?) Overall, not the place i will visit next time...

Reviews.Title: “Stayed here a few times.”
Reviews.Author: contactkalim
Reviews.Content: I stayed here a few times i visited Istanbul. Nice and comfy hotel but not a five star and the price actually does justice to the services. It has nice and comfortable rooms but not a great view (definelty not from my room). So lets start with the review: Cons: 1. Nice spaciuos smoking rooms. Very clean indeed. 2. Nice breakfast buffet. 3. Good Gym and excellent WiFi in lobby. 4. Top floor restraunt was OK. T bone steak was good. 5. Good location as in close to grocery stores. PROS: 1. Very few TV channels. It seemed they had no cable connection at all. 2. Food menu very limited. Not much to do in hotel. Got bored in 2 weeks time. 3. Lousy Laundry. They lost my beloved blue trouser. 4. Language a serious problem.

Reviews.Title: “Not bad, but not stellar”
Reviews.Author: AndyH74
Reviews.Content: I stayed in this hotel for a week in July. I agree with the other reviewers that it is not really a five star hotel. The pool is nice, the rooms clean and fairly spacious - the AC in mine worked fine, indeed very well - and the food in the hotel's restaurant was excellent, actually. But for the prices being charged you can, I am sure, find much nicer accommodation in Istanbul. The one thing readers need to be aware of is the location - the Green Park Bostanci is in, well, Bostanci. In visitor or tourist terms this is the middle of nowhere. Don't look at a map and think that you can get in and out of the city centre in minutes - Istanbul is a big city and the traffic is pretty horrendous. Though there are places to eat and shop within a fifteen minute taxi ride, and there is a taxi rank right outside the front door, the area round the hotel itself is a real wasteland in food, drink, shopping and entertainment terms. If I were coming back to Istanbul for a holiday or to visit friends I would certainly stay elsewhere, largely on the basis of location and poor value for money. If you need to be in this area of the city on business, and someone else is paying the bill, then you may have an enjoyable stay.

Reviews.Title: “OK for the Asian side”
Reviews.Author: Willigans
Reviews.Content: I stayed here because I had business nearby, but if you are traveling to Istanbul for fun you should stay on the European side of the city instead. For my needs, this place was fine but it is not convenient to the historic sites and neighborhoods that you'd want to be near for fun. There is almost nothing entertaining to do on this side of town, and absolutely nothing worthwhile a short walk from this hotel. It's billed as a 5-star place, and maybe it was 10 years ago but it is getting a little run down now. The lobby and public areas are quite nice, but several aspects of my room were worn out. For example, there is a decorative metal stripe inlay on the headboard that was peeling away at one end. The veneer on the desk was peeling in a couple of places. The bathroom ceiling was peeling in the corner and the tub desperately needed re-caulking. It was absolutely clean and well-kept, but 5-star it is not. On the plus side, I have to say that the bed was the most comfortable hotel bed I've used in years and their buffet breakfast was truly fantastic. The service was great all around, all employees were extremely helpful. Most spoke decent English, which was great because I speak no Turkish. The one dinner I had at the hotel restaurant was good though not amazing. I didn't find any other restaurant options in the area so that may be your only choice if you don't want to go some distance. I'd stay here again if I had business that required me to be on the Asian side of Istanbul.

Reviews.Title: “Very good for business trips”
Reviews.Author: U_N_Mishra
Reviews.Content: A very good hotel for business trips. Very near to business localities of asean side of Istanbul. But very Far from the tourists spots. All services are good, but restaurant has limited options and too costly. Room service and house keeping staffs barely speak English.

Reviews.Title: “Worst ever! Don't stay in this hotel!”
Reviews.Author: luohao
Reviews.Content: I have been coming to Istanbul since 2007 and from time to time I stay in this hotel which is quite close to our office. This time the experience was worst than ever! Never will I come back! Air conditioning not working, hot water oscilating from icy cold to peeling off hot! Impossible to even take a shower. No one in the lobby concerned about they assured me that they would take care of it and everything stayed exactly the same. Of course I changed hotel. Hope to have warned you sufficiently, my fellow travellers.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel, bad neighborhood”
Reviews.Author: rpcj
Reviews.Content: This is a real nice business hotel. Rooms are spacious and comfy. Breajfast room is outdated. The atbles are very close to eachother and the room is getting dirty quite quickly. Hotelbar is fine and the staff is friendly and hekpful.

Reviews.Title: “Definately NOT 5 star!!!”
Reviews.Author: Zippy-stripe
Reviews.Content: Arrived late at night to check in and was kept waiting for 15 minutes whilst the receptionist tried to find the duty manager despite my having a reservation from their website. Staff friendly enough but this is most definately not a 5 star hotel. I have stayed at many places and this is fine as a business trip hotel where you just want a bed for the night, somewhere to work and plenty of coffee/tea but I would certainly not consider it for a holiday. Pool area outside was nice enough and rooms are basic and clean though I would agree with previous comments bathrooms need attention. Air conditioning in room was useless but was good in the meeting rooms!!! As a meeting room venue, was good and restaurant was ok offering what seemed to be good Turkish food. This was probaly the best element of the hotel as a meeting venue. In general hotel would only be average for a 3-4 star hotel and falls well short of the claimed 5 star.

Reviews.Title: “Not a 5 star hotel....”
Reviews.Author: Fasted09
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for 3 nights and this is not a 5 star hotel. Service at the reception was good and the rooms were spacious. They need to look at their house keeping closely as the corner of the shower is turning black and mouldy. Breakfast was included but the food is very average and the service is not the best. At best this hotel is between a 3 and 4 star. God knows how they got a 5 star rating...this is something I love to find out. This is a business hotel as it is in the Asia side of Istanbul and near to the business district. Overall ok hotel, good night sleep (maybe I was too tired), spacious rooms, dirty bathrooms and poor service and food choice for breakfast. Would I come back....yes as it is near my office and the rooms are spacious.

Reviews.Title: “Time for Renewal and Training”
Reviews.Author: SoumiCPH
Reviews.Content: The whole experience at the Green Park is below average - from check-in to check-out. I was given a smoking room despite giving clear instructions that I have difficulty sleeping in smoking rooms especially at the Green Park as there are thick carpets and heavy drapes. They did change the room the next day as nothing worked in the room - shower, aircon, kettle. The new room was better but the aircon system was it seems switched off and with 30 degree temperatures outside it felt like sleeping in a sauna as the temperature was higher inside due to the carpets and drapes. It was the same at check out where they got the bookings mixed up and the gentleman doing the check-out was indifferent and service does not come with a smile. This is probably my worst hotel experience in Istanbul as there was not one thing I could point to that works well. I chose to skip breakfast as there are places near my office that serve nice Simit with white cheese with chai. .

Reviews.Title: “An old favorite for asian side of istanbul”
Reviews.Author: beuleu
Reviews.Content: Was for long the only business hotel on the asian side of istanbul. It is a local 5 stars that could be rated 4 for international standards. Now lots of chains are present & this hotel show his age. Nice swimming pool ( outdoor) & gym. Restaurant with lots of typical turkish food. Good wifi speed (free). Surrounding is a bit surprising with lots of auto workshops & one or 2 mosche that can surprise you in the early morning ( loudspeakers are powerful). Avoid this hotel if you want to tour istanbul, center is 1h at least ( if no jams) by car and about the same by boat ( bostanci harbour). Avoid week ends as it is a well known place for large weddings.

Reviews.Title: “Four or Three Stars will do!!!”
Reviews.Author: Yuccaflower30
Reviews.Content: My Turkish partner booked us in this hotel and from his description I felt contented as I am based outside of Turkey. Having been in a 5 star hotel last December in Istanbul I expected that this hotel will surpass my expectations, unfortunately I was reluctant to enter as its not what I expected. The location was not that eye catching, executive room was not that awesome, there were less pillows, small bathroom, the floor showed its oldness, door going to the balcony was broken, not enough movies to watch, and most of all POOR QUALITY OF AIRCONDITIONING. When you go to the balcony, you can see car repairing shops and thats not a fantastic view. We have to open the balcony door to have cold breeze from outside. Though I have said alot of negative feedbacks, this hotel got an awesome breakfast, thats for sure.

Reviews.Title: “All form and no function = 2 star satisfaction with this "5 star" hotel”
Reviews.Author: PickyBizTraveler
Reviews.Content: As I was traveling to Istanbul on business, I was very impressed that our customers have booked me into a 5 start hotel. Before leaving i have checked out this and other web sites, and was aware that the hotel was in a very middle-of-the road area, surrounded by the car repair shops and mosks, which broadcast calls to prayer at the wee hours of the morning on their loudspeakers. I did not think this was going to be an issue for me, and was correct in that regard. While I would have preferred to stay in a more touristy area with more nightlife, I was more concerned about staying close to work, and felt that this hotel would be a good compromise. As it turned out, one of the reasons my customers chose this hotel is because it allows alcohol (and there is a mini-bar in the room, as well as regular bars in the hotel), unlike some other hotels here, where owners, due to strict religious beliefs, do not allow alcohol on the property. Needless to say, my first impression of the hotel was very favorable - it is situated on a rather large property (for Istanbul), and has a decorative fense, and a gate at the entrance to the private driveway, complete with the guard. As this is my first time in istanbul, I was quite concerned about security, and this was reassuring. The front entrance is a nice rotating door, and the downstairs lobby is also clean and expensive-looking, with its marble decor. The front desk staff and the bellboy were very helpful. attentive, and friendly. However, from that point on, my impressions went downhill. As another review indicates, the "Green Park" likely reflects environmentalist aspirations of its owners. To that end, the hallway lighting supposed to be motion-sensitive - it normally stays off, until someone is moving in the hallway, at which time the motion detectors turn it on. While it sounds good on paper, the slow-acting motion sensors are combined with the fluorescent lights. As an electrical engineer, I know that fluorescent lights perform poorly in the applications that require them to frequently turn on and off, rather than stay on for prolonged periods of time, so it makes me wonder if environmentally this does more harm than good, having to dispose of mercury-filled bulbs. But I digress. The real problem is that the lights and detectors work so slowly that by the time the light starts flickering (as it heats up to turn on), you have already passed it. In addition, the rooms have a key-card holder slot by the front door, which requires you to insert the card in for the room lights to come on. I have trouble fitting the card into this slot, especially since once I reach my door and stop moving, the hallway lights turn off, so there is darkness both behind and in front of me. OK, I am not particularly afraid of the dark, but even to me it is extremely annoying. The room is rather large and is decorated nicely, at least visually. There is a wardrobe by the entrance, where you can hang up your stuff on hangers with non-removable hooks (I hate being treated like a criminal). However, unless your suitcase is very small, you can leave it either on the floor, or on top of a low dresser-trunk at the far end of the room - not very well thought out. The room has a narrow work surface, an armchair, a small round table and an upholsered chair. There is also a mini-fridge, with an LCd TV on top, and a bed. Having arrived late at night, and having to go to work the next day, I have given my attention to the bed first. It is covered with soft white linens (a bed-sheet and a comforter, and in addition to the two synthetic pillows, it has three more decorative pillows and a matching runner. While it looks nice, you have to remove the pillows and the runner from the bed to sleep in it. Herein lies the problem - there is no place to put them on, except on the floor. Of course, the next day housekeepers place them back onto the bed, which makes me wonder about the hygienics of this setup. Before falling asleep I wanted to plug in my computer - the front desk staff have given me a power adaptor; however, it fwas designed to adapt from the British three prong system, rather than from the american one. There is only one british-type receptacle in the room, by the desk, rather than by the bed, so if you, like me need to plug anything ini by the bed, you are out of luck. There are some european-type receptacles by the bed, but you will need to get your own adapter (next day). Still, this was a minor problem. The bathroom is relatively small, especially matched to a room this size, but adequate for a single person. Two people would have trouble maneuvering around each other. The low-flow shower head is OK, and gives adequate amout of water. The shower-bath tub has a sliding glass door, and it feels rather narrow, although when I look at it it seems to be standard width. The towels are thick and soft. Next day I came down for breakfast, which was included with the room rate (this is a fairly standard practice in these parts of the world), and was impressed by the spread. There was about a dozen kinds of cheezes, fresh cucumbers and tomatoes (both with the skin removed), a dozen types of pastries, smoked salmon slices, desserts, cereals, as well as a number of chafing dishes with various hot items (such as grilled halloumi (hellum, as they call it) cheeze, in addition to the omlette station. Over the next days I came to appreciate this breakfast even more. However, the staff, while generally friendly, sometimes seemed a bit overwhelmed, and on a couple of occasions ignored/disregarded/forgot about my repeated requests for a coffee - no big deal, I can pour my own coffe, but this is not a 5-star service. Next evening, after work I decided to check out the TV. While it has probably 2 dozen channels, most of them are in Turkish (understandably so). In addition, there are several German channels, a french, italian, greek channel. There is only one English language channel, and this is the deplorable BBC News. This is very surprising in a hotel geared for business. There is also a Russian-language channel, but it did not work - kept showing garbled video (although it was working in other areas of the hotel). There are also pay-per-view movies, but they are very expensive (around E20 each, or $26 USD). I would not spend this much money on a movie in a theater, let alone on a diminutive TV screen, and besides, I make it a practice not to watch hotel movies while on business- this avoids having the boss ask you suspicious questions, and the colleagues snickering, about the nature of the movies. This is also the case wtih all of my colleagues who travel on business, so I don't know of anyone who considers the overpriced moves a viable form of in-room entertainment. So I turn to Internet - the hotel does advertise wireless internet. Indeed there is a service; however, it is very weak (the bars are showing red) and expensive - E11 (nearly $15) a day, a little cheaper if you pay for a week at a time. In addition, like most elsewhere in Turkey. the connection is slow (no more than 15 KB per second), and it is filtered. You can not access any web sites of questionable moral stature, including YouTube, due to government-mandated filtering, and besides, location awareness prevents you from getting to your favorite US network sites (such as USAnetwork.com, which has full episodes of its various shows).On the positive side, I was able to make a VPN connection to my company's servers, albeit a very slow one. For all its good looks, the bed is extremely hard - I wonder if there are any springs in it. While the mattress does not feel lumpy, it has very little padding, and after the tiredness of the trans-atlantic flight wore out, I started having trouble sleeping on it. Also of note, the upholstered chair looks expensive, but its seat cushion has no support. So when you sit down on it, all you feel is the wood at the front edge of the chair - this ranges from uncomfortable to painful, after even a short time. The first few nights sleeping was OK - the room has funky windows that open two ways - either the top end swings in, or the entire window opens swinging to the side. The weather was cool, and the open windows did the trick, despite the prayer calls from the mosks, and the soccer games that some excited youths were paying just under my windows (I don't know if this field is a part of the hotel complex or not, but there is a lot of noise). There is also loud music playing outside, and occasional sirens blaring (there is a big hospital across the street). But all of the above are relatively minor peeves, compared to what followed. As the days (and nights) warmed up, the nights became more and more uncomfortable. It turns out that even though there was a thermostat in the room, adjusting it has practically no effect on the room environment. It looks that either due to their environmental zeal, or in an attempt to save money (I think "Green Park" has some meaning here, too), they put in an inadquate air conditioning system into the hotel. So when I had talked to the front desk, they spread their arms and apologetically said, "we know, but we have a central system... Perhaps it will work better tonight". I don't think I will be taking a chance to find out - I am checking out tomorrow, to move to a different hotel. Indeed, all the service of the staff means nothing if the visitors are uncomfratable ini the inadequate facility. Based on my experience, I would not recommend it, particularly in the warm seasons (probably may to October around here).

Reviews.Title: “depends what you want”
Reviews.Author: FranWilson
Reviews.Content: This hotel had some great facilities. The heated pool was wonderful. The steam room and sauna were great. The fitness centre well equipped. The turkish bath was, however, unfortunately, broken. The breakfast was fabulous - an enormous diverse spread of a range of local turkish goods as well as the more standard european fare. We used the bar, which although it was expensive, provided lots of great free snacks on the side that we really appreciated at the end of a long day. The food in the restaurant was not worth the price, however, and this is a shame as the options nearby are limited. We were here for a business meeting and in that sense, everything was great. Especially the little sweet treats with the afternoon coffee! While we got free internet access for the meeting, the cost to have it in our room was rather high. It is a strange trend that business hotels charge a fortune for internet access that is offered free in many smaller, more tourist catering places! Also, be warned, this hotel is not in a great part of town if you want to explore Istanbul as you need to take a taxi everywhere. If you need a place to host a conference in Istanbul, this may be a good option for you. If you are wanting a place to stay as a tourist, you may want to keep looking.

Reviews.Title: “Enough..but not for a 5 star”
Reviews.Author: Klinefelter
Reviews.Content: 1. Aspect: Above Average 2. Location: Average 3. Service: Average 4. Rooms: Average 5. Breakfast: Okay, but some problems 6. Restaurant: Above Average 7. Spa: (no answer) 8. Comments: I think you can find better if you look for, but for business purpose it is enough.

Reviews.Title: “Ripoff every step of the way”
Reviews.Author: SirFliesAAAlot
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Green Park Bostanci hotel while in the Asianatic side of Istanbul on business. Travel agent negotiated a 90 EUR nightly rate for the company that I was visiting. When I checked in, the rate had gone to 130 EUR. When I had the company that I was visiting contact the hotel to correct the rate, they refused to do so saying that I could cancel but they would charge the full amount to my card. Additionally, the restraunt is poor - I was the only customer in there and they were playing Bryan Adams love songs at full volume. If you like to eat lamb then you might be in for a treat, but if you don't want any lamb your only option is the spaghetti (without meatballs, since those are made from lamb). Breakfast buffet, while free, consists of orange juice (watered down), bread, and olives. Who eats olives for breakfast? The rooms are relatively soundproof, except for the 5x daily call to prayer from the mosque next door (broadcast on loudspeaker, especially at midnight and sunrise). The air conditioners don't cool the room, instead, they keep it relatively heat-free. Don't open the windows unless you love mosquitoes and noise from the various car repair shops directly across the street. For being an 'international business and event hotel', the staff here speaks remarkably poor English. Don't expect any help with directions or anything more complicated than checking in and ordering a taxi.
